The Pixel has a way better software experience : stock Android, faster and smoother, more reliable, and it's still up to date !
 
Overall photo quality is great for both devices : Pixel is a bit better at dayshots, V20 a bit better at nightshots. Pixel is a "point-and-shoot" device, it has no manual mode.
 
Video recording is better for the V20 overall : Pixel has better stabilization, but it's nightshots are garbage.
 
V20 has micro SD slot, Pixel's not (but unlimited native quality, storage photos and videos via Google Photos)
 
V20 is 5,7 inch, if you like bigger screens.
 
I personnally choose Pixel for the software experience and smaller size, but V20 is cheaper and better for video recording, it's still a great shot.
 
Pick what you need most, it's up to you.

Can't belive the "12 mp really?" comment.  Pixel number is just a marketing trick to attract consummers. You can have a 8mp camera that will produce much, much better pictures than a 16mp camera.  The real picture quality actually depends on the lens number, quality, material (plastic versus glass), picture processing (software), sensor physical dimensions.  If engineers would get a 16mp phone camera and replace the sensor with a 8mp one, they will be able to get a much better picture quality.  In fact, the more the pixels, the harder is to get a good picture quality.

Man, the Pixel have only 12.3mp cause this helps for having a very big pixel size (1.55 on the pixel). This means that if you have bigger pixel size, the density of the shots is very big and the photos even zoomed are still very clear and sharp. Having 41 megapixels on an sensor that small is stupidity. To fill so much megapixels you need an sensor that size is 6-7 times biger than the pixel one. When there are more megapixels there is smaller pixel size (making photos less clear and noisy) and having less megapixels lead to a bigger pixel size(make photos very sharp and clear, even on zooming). Hope you understood!

So I done some research and not all was good but you get that with everything. 
I decided to go with it anyway. 
The design is great I love how it looks, I like the fingerprint sensor at the back too. 
It's kind of iPhone looking but with android so if you're an iPhone fan but hate restrictions this could be the phone for you. 
This however is where my opinion changes. 
The volume button is on the wrong side and placed perfectly so when it's in an in car holder the volume gets pressed, very annoying. 
The phone is not as fast as I expected. 
The camera was disappointing compared to Samsung and even my iPhone 5. 
The first thing that happened when I put my sim in and started downloading apps was a "force close" type thing. 
It crashed everything I tried for the first hour. 
Afterwards it improved long enough to have a play but still threw me out of apps and games randomly until day 4. 
Performance was however quite slow considering. 
Then when playing games my Internet was constantly dropping out on WiFi, I contacted my service provider 7 times and in the end had an engineer visit to fix my net but there was nothing wrong with it, he had an old Samsung like the first smart phone ever and he was streaming videos fine. it turns out the pixel has a WiFi connection issue since it was returning speeds of 30mbps and although stayed connected had no Internet connection, totally unreliable. 
Mobile signal was strong though, where I would normally get no signal or very little I was picking up 2 bars + happily.
 
I got rid of the pixel after just 6 days of owning it, I'd had enough of the faults and quite honestly what I was led to believe was great performance camera etc etc. 
All very disappointing. 
Also the battery life wasn't that good considering the battery that's powering it. 
I now have a galaxy S6 again I'm getting Internet speeds over WiFi of 130mbps and no connectivity issues. 
Camera is very good. 
Performance feels faster than the pixel. 
It's the same size as the pixel well a little bigger. 
Battery is about the same as the pixel. 
And Web browsing is of ease where as the pixel some things were awkward to navigate and adverts with multiple pictures were where the pixel got stuck as it didn't give you the arrows or tap to change to see all the other pics.
 
Highly recommend staying away from this phone!!
 
Samsung is allot nicer to look at and hold. 
Everything works well even apps feel like they were designed for the phone.

People don't need to justify their reasons for wanting an SD Card. Just because you don't need one, doesn't mean others don't. Also, why should it be "valid" in your eyes? 
Maybe someone puts a lot of work in something you may not find valid or justified. Buy nevertheless that person cares. 
Personally I do so many things with my 32GB Cass 10 card: 
- Over 20.000 photos (im into graphics, photoshop) 
- APK kits and backups (in case there's no light, no Internet) 
- Usually I download torrents straight on my phone 
- Some videos, clips 
- Music and e-books 
- Documents, pdfs 
- And the most important thing, I keep my ROMs on my SD Card. Whenever I feel like, I get in recovery, erase everything and flahs a new ROM without the need of cables. 
I won't tell you how many files I've lost for having them on the internal memory. I'm into extreme de-bloating, playing with the OS, changing it how I want it and many times when something goes wrong you get bootloops, which basically means you lost everything on the internal memory and you need to reflash the ROM. 
ALSO, you can drop your phone, get it wet, render it useless, BUT you can always get the SD Card out and all your data si safe. 
The cloud thing isn't for everyone.  For one I barely use it. What happens if you have no Internet?  Ups! 
Also, I don't want my data on fuggle's hard drives.  
The bottom line is people still use them, still need them and we are many. When I pay a lot of cash on a HIGH-END smartphone there are some features that I demand. This is how the market goes. People ask and others provide. I always want waterproof and SD Card or I'm not interested from the start, no matter how gorgeous or shiny or GOOD the phone is. 
A highend smartphone on Android without SD Card is not highend in my eyes and many others that are into IT, graphics, photography and the list goes on.

It matters, yes. They're ran on a different pipeline, so if you want to copy data from the USB port to the microSD, you actually get faster speeds than simply slitting the USB port. I use my phone to clone SD cards, for photography purposes. 
 
Having data on the SD card also means it doesn't get uploaded to the cloud, which is good because I don't always want to upload things to the cloud. Most cloud services I know of have been compromised at some point or other.
 
SSDs also have limited write cycles, so if you're constantly writing data that you're obtaining from the cloud, it will lessen the lifespan of the phone considerably.
 
How does it negatively impact the customer? I understand from the manufacturers point of view it makes sense not to include a microSD card slot because they can sell the more expensive phone with more storage, but please remind me what your issue is against having a microSD card slot.

As boring as the iphone. No dual sim. No sd card. No ir blaster. Chunky body that doesn't translate to marathon battery life. Overkill screen resolution that doesn't serve any purpose other than giving a marginally better VR experience that nobody is going to bother after a few nauseating experiences or after the novelty fades. Google assistant? You only talk to your phone at home or when driving unless you want to look silly in public talking loudly to a phone. For this, get an Amazon echo or Google's copycat version. And the price? Forget it. You can have the same or better specs and features at half the price elsewhere. Try oneplus or xiaomi or oppo or vivo. So what is the target market of this phone? Iphone switchers? Nope. Samsung flagship users? Nope. Nexus owners? Yes, but only a very small percentage as most Nexus owners value price:performance over prestige. In short, this phone is going to flop big time unless it captures if not all, at least most of the features android enthusiasts want in an android phone. High on the list for many android users aside from good camera and video (given) are sd card support, removable or large 4000mAh+ batteries, water resistance, ir blaster, wireless and/or fast charging, dual sim support, slimport or mhl support, option for larger (6.0"-6.8") screen sizes.

Nobody bats an eye to Google Nexus devices, period. Many Huawei and Xiaomi phones have outsold Nexus devices. Google Nexus/Pixel devices are niche. Google is not a hardware company. They rely on Samsung and others to help sell Android which helps Google sell mobile ads. They lack retail stores for true aftercare services. They lack an ecosystem since any mobile browser in any platform can work their services. 
 
What is special about this Pixel device? Nothing except fastest software updates. Nexus devices were never really best at the features they offered. Samsung doesn't offer anything new but they excel at hardware aspects like display, battery life, camera, and recently design. Not in any given year prior was a Nexus device ever the best smartphone of the year. They never excelled in camera and battery life. They never had the best displays or audio. They no longer hold a price advantage. 
 
2010 - Nexus One, Nexus S. Not the best that year. Went to iPhone 4.
 
2011 - Galaxy Nexus. Not the best. Weak TI OMAP SoC. Best was probably S2, 4s, N9, or first Note. 
 
2012 - Nexus 4. Weak glass and battery life. Poor camera and washed out display. Best was probably iPhone 5 or Note II. 
 
2013 - Nexus 5. Same issues as predecessor. Best was Note 3 surpassing LG G2... 
 
2014 - Nexus 6. Probably the first truly excellent Nexus. But best still goes to Note 4 surpassing it, OnePlus One, iPhone 6 Plus, and HTC One M8. Last Note with removable battery. 
 
2015 - Nexus 6P, Nexus 5X. Best probably was another Samsung with the S6 edge or + variant. Note5 took a step backwards. 
 
2016 - Pixel, Pixel XL. Note7, S7 edge, iPhone 7 Plus, and maybe LG V20 surpasses this. 
 
The last 4-5 years a Samsung had the best overall phone even if Google's oil don't mix well with Samsung's vinegar. Samsung should leave Android. That's Samsung's main Achilles. Their software skin is no good on Android. But they excel in hardware and the only true OEM out there. 
 
All you are buying is for faster software updates with Google devices. It isn't BEST in any other aspect except maybe in Android speed tests. It loses in many other areas and have zero hope it tops in camera and battery life being an HTC. Refuse to buy phones that lacks microSD slot. These Pixels are no better than the HTC 10 and OnePlus 3 with just Nougat 7.1 on it.
